posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26359003
>basically do offer the same protection
They basically pass the same artificial lab test, keyword being "artificial". You pay extra for fiberglass shell that doesn't shatter like poly (carbon is a bit of a meme good mostly for reducing weight), better inserts (density stratification matters), more shell sizes (fit matters), better interior finish (sweat is a thing), better fine fit options (peel off inserts are a thing), better airflow (i like to breathe, it's fun), more optional extras (tinted visors are kinda nice).... there is a lot of things you pay extra for in a helmet. And getting back to the "just as good" in the safety department, just because both have the "you will probably not die" sticker on doesn't mean both protect the same from those non-lethal injuries, TBI is no fun. But that is my view on that.

>>26354206
The one thing you're forgetting is that cars last longer than ever as of the 90's, as long as you don't live in a road salt shithole.

Prior to the 90's in the carburetor days, cars were irredeemable shitpiles by 100k miles because the engine was so full of carbon deposits and everything was so worn out it would need a top to bottom rebuild to be usable unless it was pristinely cared for by a mechanic owner.

Now, thanks to modern fuel injection, it seems to be the norm that engines will last to 300k miles if maintained and transmissions will last 100-200k and sometimes more for certain ones in specific applications. This means that the days of buying a minimalist shitbox makes less sense when you can buy a few years old nicer car with plenty of life left in it. It was this shift towards buying a nice used car over a new shitbox that killed the cheap new car.

The other thing that killed the cheap new car was ever-increasing regulations that make it cost-prohibitive to even produce a cheap car because by the time you get all of the approvals and certs you need to even sell it, it's no longer affordable. Really government is the problem, you can buy a motorcycle all day long and goofy shit like a 3 wheel Polaris Slingshot, but the second it's on 4 wheels it needs 6000 airbags, to be able to withstand artillery shells to every body panel yet also somehow be cushy for pedestrian faggots, etc. Cars need to go back to being glorified golf carts again, we got along just fine with those.

>>26354287

Not really. I spend 50 minutes per day driving and have free parking at home and at work. My colleagues who use transit spend 120+ minutes per day commuting. They are losing ~6 hours per week of their life to take transit. They spend $200/month on their transit passes and my insurance is $120/month. Add gas and maintenance and I'm only spending about an extra $50/week more than they do, and I have the convenience of owning a car, which I can use for road trips and errands.

So I spend $50 per week to save myself ~6 hours per week. I make $40/hr, so that's a really good deal for me. And if you're going to argue that transit is better than driving because you can read or whatever and you can't do that while driving, then I would tell you that you're a poser whos never used transit. When you ride transit in rush hour it's not comfortable and you can't realistically read or enjoy the experience. The only thing you can do is listen to a podcast or audiobook or something else auditory, which, guess what, you can also do in a car.

The only time when transit matches or beats a car for commuting is when you live right downtown in the center of a big, dense urban core. As someone who did that, I can tell you it's hell on earth. I will never live in a glass/steel skyscraper jungle ever again. No thanks. I like my peace and quiet and actually seeing green.

posts.com:
Because the Hummer is big and dumb, always was, and nobody normal needs a Hummer. Most people remember the H2 which was a mall crawler predominantly bought by women and built on an Escalade chassis.

If you are part of the .01% of society that actually needs a Hummer, you can buy a real humvee straight from a government auction. My friends used it as an emergency tow truck/winter truck around Reno. Worked great but was also very cold and drafty versus a normal car, and very hard to drive. Most people I know would rather just take a snow day then put in the effort needed to 4x4 to work. Also, the CJ Willys is an objectively better vehicle by every margin. You can still get a CJ Willys or just a base model Wrangler which is the same thing but usable on freeways.

When the idea was brought up to me initially about this site, I said no because the pastebin & spreadsheet exist. I also stated that certain vendors should be removed because some of the content that they make isn't exactly geared towards the people here and people would find it irritating to see, amongst other reasons. Taiyo made the decision to keep everyone the way it is, and I stand with him on that even though I would have acted differently initially.

I would only suggest to him to remove someone if they were actively scamming, dead website, false advertising and so on. Yes, I'm waiting for someone to mention how ironic this is coming from me and my previous fuck up handling order fulfillment, but that's way beyond the point.

I understand your frustration, Taiyo and I look at other vendor's behaviors (and even my own) and try to avoid either repeating mistakes or going down a similar path someone else did. In my own opinion when it comes to non-OSG vendors, I wouldn't get my hopes up. This isn't a critique about Super Effective either, but for example if you encounter stores with pre-orders, poorly printed apparel being sold at ridiculous prices, various type of coomer products and etc without easy channels to reach them on their page, I wouldn't be surprised at the lack of support because they've made and spent enough money on other things and furthering their own business to give a shit about having a proper system for customer support. I'll repeat, this isn't a hit piece on them or any other vendor specifically, but you'll know what to watch out for when you see it enough times.

Again, I think keeping them is beneficial (unless for reasons including but not limited to the aforementioned for removal). Of course, you are welcome to discuss any other ideas and I will share them with Taiyo in a VC if he does not read them here first. If the complaints generated against SE are that overwhelming, we will take action now and in the future.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26335660
#1 is correct. Again, I'm completely on board with you. If enough people point out that there's an issue with someone or if there's evidence of foul play then we'll take care of it because we don't want people throwing away their money because we didn't clean up the site. Granted, the review system was an impromptu idea, there may or may not be better alternatives that I haven't thought out. A benefit of a review system is being able to see the frequency of getting a blem in the mail, consistent shipping times, re-stocks, etc. So even though a vendor may not fit the criteria for deletion for messing up a few orders or not having good QC, it'll be up to the buyer's discretion to use this information of how to spend their money. It's also provides the benefit of vendors not being able to hide negative reviews as a third party repository. I can assure you that if people wanted to say things about me and what happened last time, Taiyo wouldn't delete it and he would stop working with me if I suggested censorship to save a couple of bucks. My way of rectifying the whole order fulfillment mess is to completely eliminate stamped shipping and pre-orders to minimize lead-times as much as possible and I intend to prove that when the store re-opens and how I reveal products.

My personal take on your situation is that it's a mishap, Super Effective and Catch My Drift are basically one entity from my understanding and have a reasonably large following and put out a lot of product with what seems to be mostly satisfied customers. They also outsource the printing like many other vendors (including me), so there's always going to be blems unless you're the one handling production or paying them enough money to give enough of a shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26356900
You need to phrase your question better, do you mean total mileage regardless of age or mileage per year?

I'd say 10k miles or less is still "like new", that's usually what collectors go after for cars.

However, I think the ideal is a consistent 1-3k miles per year because that means the car was used enough to keep fluids circulating, varmints from nesting in it, etc. More than that they're wearing it out, less than that it will have problems from sitting too much.

All of this said, the thing I find most important for any car is care and maintenance. Mileage almost doesn't matter unless you're talking hundreds of thousands, what matters far more is following scheduled maintenance, not jumping speed bumps and driving around town bouncing off the rev limiter, keeping throttle and revs low while warming up, etc.

>>26351098
I don't think this is good advice at all. The majority of good cars that are about 15-20 years old have actually climbed in price in the last 3 years. Old but reliable cars (like a corolla, civic, camry, accord, etc) have actually been an appreciating asset. This probably won't continue but the point is that a 10 year old car, if taken care of and a good make/model, will lose very little value over 5 years. Even less if it's 15 years old. A 2002 Corolla is essentially the same price as a 2007. Depreciation stops being significant after about 15 years or so.

On the other hand, a brand new car will drop in value like a rock over 5 years. Look at any 2017 car right now and compare it to what it was selling for in 2017. Even in this crazy market they're still down 30%.

I kind of think that with cars there's a sweet spot at the beginning and end, but the middle doesn't make as much sense. Buying new makes sense if you know what you're doing and you take care of your car (and buy something good), because you can use it for decades if you want to. Buying 10+ years old makes sense, too, because you can buy something that is still a very good product for quite cheap. I don't think buying ~4-6 years old makes much sense. >>26358422
for the rust you can chip around the area with a flathead to look for any other rust. Once finished spray some rust remover on it and then sand it down with an angle grinder. vacuum all the dust, wipe down with alcohol, and apply rustoleum

For using bondo, sand around the area (bare metal) to which you want to apply. Feather the area with 80 grit sandpaper. And finally begin applying bondo. You'd want to always use a bit more bondo than you'd need. Once the bondo is hardened enough use a hand block with 36 grit for final rendering.

I embedded the link in case you'd need any more clarification of what not to do.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rtUoaRxmgAg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358431
>fix it properly
>bondo
Remove all the loose stuff and weak metal you can, wire brush what's left, use ospho or some sort of phosporic acid-based rust converter on any exposed (but still rusty) metal, then put a nice layer of POR15 over all that from the inside and out (and a zinc primer, might be overkill/unnecessary).
Once that's done, I'd try to get at it from the inside and try to either use one of those metal mesh "bondo patch" things, or better yet mix some fiberglass resin with cut-out pieces of fiberglass cloth to build up a "backing" around the antenna. You can build up a few layers of cloth + resin if needed to make a more firm surface.
Once you've got a more solid surface built back up around the area (which will likely be bigger once you strip the rust back), then you can start with using something such as bondo glass (fiberglass reinforced), switch to regular bondo after that, spot putty and sand, then finally you're ready for a filler primer and then paint.

The 'true' proper way to permanently fix it would obviously be replacing the panel, but I've used my solution a few times on rusty cars with good results plus it usually requires less than $100 total in supplies. It'll last a few years before you start to see some bubbling coming back, at the very least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26347325
They're cheap at pull-a-part yards and easy to harvest. Self and bro pull 5.3 and 6.0 in a couple of hours by recip sawing the frame rails on vans and trucks. There are plenty of 4.8s because no one wants small engines and since the 4L60E trannies die long before the engines it's easy to find good ones. Don't bother with anything rusty or nasty or flood damaged as engines abound especially if you go 4.8. Once the work is done you could do a 6.0 drop-in but a 4.8 would be a great fit for an S-10.

LSDroid will swap .bin files and Universal Patcher mods them easily. I use an OBDX VT and a Fire 10 (2021) bought for the purpose but phones will do. Make a bench harness out of one "blue" PCM connector and an OBD connector (cheap online or harvest with a blue PCM connector from another vehicle.

Get ALL the harness you can harvest and get the drive-by-wire pedal. We bring a shitload of black zip ties to wrap the harness to the engine. Get the fuse box. When you pay for a complete engine be damn sure you get one. That includes any modules connected to the engine harness. Get all the hardware you remove too. We bring a modded garden wagon with solid tires packed with tools.

Diablo Auto Dismantling blades are love.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26347325
More LS donor raep:

We rotate engines by the damper bolt when examining them and use a bright light down the oil filler. We have several sets of these to stabilize our engines in transport and bolt them on while the engines are hanging off the forklift:

https://www.amazon.com/Chevy-LSx-Engine-Storage-Stand/dp/B01N7W87BH

You can do the complete LS & tranny pull with fairly few tools. We bring 3/8" and 1/2" cordless impacts and the usual breaker bars and cheater pipes. While a good recip saw can cut the front off a truck or van on one battery and using only one Diablo blade, buy the blades by the box and bring two recip saws if you have smart help. With frame rails severed the torsion bars control the drivetrain when it tilts forward. A very useful tool is an angle head electric ratchet. We have 1/4" and 3/8" drive. The Harbor Freight long neck angle head 3/8 drive fits so many places we both bought one and my bro leaves his 3/8 Milwaukee at home. Long, very long, and short extensions are your friends. So is a set of metric six point 1/4" drive sockets and ratchet for many small jobs. If you've not done much salvage remember it's customary to cut out long seat belt sections to tie (firmly!) as engine lift slings if you don't own commercial ones.

You could pull and sell LS (and trannies, 4L80Es sell easy as do good 4L60Es which are not common) to pay for your own project and just keep the best engine for yourself.

pull-a-part yards sometimes place the support rims (junk rims welded together) too far forward for balance reasons. We put extra weight in the very back of the SUV like two or three wheel and tire assemblies so salvage staff can move the supports as far back as possible.

Put your truck to work making you money before modding it. The way to get toys is use your wrenching skills to make toy money. It's easy to drown in trucks and parts if you have room for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
on one hand they are generally driven carelessly by renters and porters so you might have some cosmetic imperfections, but the rental company takes advantage of warranties and insurance just like normal people and can affect their own repairs, so you get a car where any major potential problems (such as manufacturing defects that affect whole batches or models) will have reared their head and been fixed long before you buy it.
collisions will have been documented. oil changes will have been done, not regularly or with fancy oil or anything but done. you do still have to be concerned about wear items like brakes and bearings, as well as items with no service schedule like transmissions with "lifetime fill" change this stuff immediately because the rental company won't do shit that is not still under mfg. warranty or required by law before selling it to you.
look up the carfax, or manufacturer build sheet and determine where the car spent its work life before buying. you do not want a northern ex-rental car, obviously.
in some respects it's safer than just buying the same car off fbm from some rando who just finished paying it off and may or may not have done any service

Year 2000 I was 21 years old. Living in norcal somewhat close to the bay area. Saved for a year and dead set on buying a new white integra gs-r. Good friend worked at a toyota dealership. He asked me to swing by and test drive the new celica gt-s. Told him I didn't want to waste his time and I had made up my mind on the integra. He said he knew but wanted me to test drive it anyway. Dealership was next to a couple of freeways. We both took it out. Was mild with the throttle at first. He told me to rev the shit out of it. So I did. Was actually impressed with toyotas version of vtec, but the body had too much roll to it in turns. Up and down the freeway revving the hell out of it. Pulled back to the dealership and the engine was clunking. Both looked at each other wide eyed and walked away. Later I told him I was sorry. He said he didn't know what I was talking about. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26357406
Completely disagree with this. In my province of British Columbia they implemented this over 10 years ago. While it was mainly chinks in their high powered exotic cars racing around Vancouver that led to civil forfeiture being a thing, here's the problem with that: Around the same time they also implemented short to longer term impounds of vehicles for street racing. So you'll lose your ride for at least 7 days, pay a hefty fine plus towing/storage costs, and possibly lose your license if you have prior history of racing/stunting. I believe this to be more than enough to handle anyone that's a problem. Now, while I have no problems with rich Hongers getting fucked here, police are given a wide margin of discretion on when to simply impound, or seize for civil forfeiture. Stunting/street racing here encompasses a variety of things... Simply burning rubber could technically get your shit seized for forfeiture, although I'm not aware of this happening. Simply spinning your tires on a slick wet street could get your shit impounded, whether you meant to or not. The law here is very vague, in what you can do and can't do, and what repercussions you may face. Of course we all have our chance in court here to 'tell it to the judge', but never before has civil forfeiture been a thing here for vehicles unless they were proven to be bought by proceeds of crime (drug dealers), or utilized in a serious crime (robbing a bank). The threshold for forfeiture has dropped too low now, where spinning tires in the wet could be considered stunting, which is now considered stunting, now considered a serious crime, leading to possible seizure.

>>26356771
First: Make sure you're using the right size socket, it shouldn't be loose at all, but very snug. Make sure it's all the way on, tap it a bit if you need to. Also make absolutely sure you're turning it the correct direction (counter clockwise as you face the bolt)

After you've confirmed all those, put a small metal pipe on it (hardware store if you dont have anything) and use that to give you more leverage. You can go as big or small as you need to break it loose, pic related is a big pipe, but a small pipe will help.

Make sure the ratchet doesn't start to slip as you put pressure on it, you don't want to round off the bolt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26356712
tires lose air in the winter when it gets cold. its the basic ideal gas law. odds are you dont have anything wrong with your tires
look at the driver door panel, there will be a sticker that says what PSI to inflate your tires to. this should be near the latch, and itll be yellow and white. you can go to a gas station where they have coin op pumps or buy your own compressor from Home Depot for $30. Buy a tire gauge if you don’t have one. Fill the tires up to the pressure specced on the sticker, 35 PSI is usually the standard for passenger cars
oil changes are also simple, just google “year make model engine oil change” and chances are someone has done a youtube video for it. Oil changes require at a minimum ramps/jack + stands, a drain pan, and a socket set, so if you dont have those you’ll need to get them. its best to have someone help you with your first oil change so you know the ins and outs of doing it properly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26357806
The reason they say to leave it is because in an auto box that's rarely/never had it's oil changed, large pieces of crap can build in certain parts.
Draining and refilling the box risks dislodging these parts as air bubbles circulate the self-bleeding mechanisms on start-up.

Personally, I prefer to risk the box and change the oil rather than drive with what amounts to used engine oil circulating through my transmission.

Look up parts too, some auto boxes have their own oil filter.
And be aware; some auto gearboxes require equipment to change the oil.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26358046
econ major here. It depends on your interest rate, your tolerance of risk/loss, and your time horizon. Over a long enough time horizon, the stock market will beat everything else. In a shorter window of time, however, the stock market is volatile and you're at risk of losing money.

The long term average return of stocks is about 9-10% but that will likely drop a bit in the near future as economic growth slows, so perhaps think of it as more like 8%. Bonds have been forgotten thanks to decades of low interest rates. The problem with bonds is that the safe ones, like government bonds, pay very little. GIC's are guaranteed but they only pay a low yield. I don't even know what they're paying these days because I forgot they existed since we had 20 years of near zero interest rates. They were paying ~2-3% for a while. Perhaps they're up around 4% now or might be soon.

Even if interest rates go up, I still doubt that any "safe" investment would beat your interest payments on your car. Pretty much the only way to beat it is if you have excellent credit and get a low rate, and then invest your money in stocks. Of course, invest it in a non-retarded way, like in a REIT or index fund or ETF.

But if I'm being honest with you, you don't sound like someone who's very familiar with all of this and given that you'd probably be better off just buying the car outright. I honestly think that Toyota has the solution to simulated 4WD systems with selective FWD biased AWD. The biggest problem is always wheel slip and selective brake application does fine in most cases in controlling that. It offers a level of control that isn't possible with a driver.

With the right control algorithms, it'll likely replace 4WD in consumer applications, relegating full time 4WD/AWD and lockers to hobbyist/specialty applications. Now that cars don't have to navigate terrain blind with wheel speed, yaw, pitch rate sensors, they'll probably integrate their radar and camera systems to scan its surroundings. I can't imagine how nightmarishly complex a system like this would have to be, but the compute capacity for industrial computation is there. I would wager that CAN-FD standard does not have enough data throughput to support that right now, and a new ISO standard will have to be implemented for the high data throughputs that are necessitated for even basic things like a truly intelligent, terrain-aware 4WD/AWD system, let alone fully autonomous driving. Automakers had better get very good at sealing electrical components, and also add in a fuck ton of grounding redundancies that don't involve braided copper straps (LOOKING AT YOU GM), otherwise these systems will fail in incredibly stupid ways.

With that said, there will always be holdouts that will prefer the mechanical systems, and they will have their place. Personally I think the best solution always has a failsafe. Most applications won't need it, and therefore won't have it.

>>26355886
A lot of people have issues welding because they're trying to use it like a hot glue gun.
And learning on exhaust pipe is rough.
I'd suggest practicing on thicker material.
Also try to find a video on "trigger welding", where you just do individual spot welds instead of running a bead. It's a training technique so you can focus on learning to recognize when the material is hot enough to accept the filler material but not turn completely molten and drip onto the floor.

Theoretically it's enough to connect to any piece of bare metal on the main chassis. >>26357720
Much better car. Than the civic, and notably better than the last generation 986.

986s had notably high IMS bearing issues. They claim it was lower (like 10%ish i believe), but I personally have had 2 failures. One on an original bearing at 90k miles, another on a 2nd replaced double row IMS bearing at 140k miles with only 30k miles on the bearing. Two different cars, the Finland-made and Stuttgart-made.

987s still had some IMS issues although I think the reported failure rate is still notable. I think it's between 2-5% reported. Still something to worry about as it's not fucking cheap to replace an entire engine.

These cars really fall apart when they sit. Dunno why but a lot of german cars do. As soon as they get parked for an extended period they just degrade quickly. Fuel pumps always go first when they get parked for like 2 weeks to a month.

Find a car that gets regular mileage but is maintained, and for these cars it's worth paying a couple extra grand to get a good one. Someone who is retarded and got overpriced service for it. Considers it a baby or something gay like that.

posts.name: Anonymous

I only start downshifting if I have a feeling that traffic might start moving again before I come to a stop. If I'm coming up to a light that just turned red or a stop sign, I'll coast in neutral and brake gently

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358665
you can also just leave it in gear and brake only. some people are worried about wearing out a clutch doing this but if you rev match this is no problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358665
Slow down be it through just coasting with the clutch up and the car slowing down on its own, or using the brakes, then when the car reaches it's idle rpm, clutch in and keep the clutch in until you stop. That's only if you are 100% certain you are going to stop. If you think the traffic lights are gonna go green before you get there, slow down to like 15mph, clutch in, go into 2nd gear, clutch up so you're able to accelerate immediately if the lights change. If they don't change to green, brake until idle rpm, clutch in when you've reached idle rpm all the way to a stop.

absolutely retarded faggot here.

my mechanic serviced my water pump earlier today because it was leaking. the work was done under warranty so i suspected he didn’t burp my coolant system properly when I read on the invoice that he simply allowed it to “reach operating temperature”. more, there was a small sloshing noise in my heater core during acceleration, implying air in the system. so, i burped it myself when I got home.

idled the engine for twenty minutes with one of those tall coolant funnels attached to the radiator, allowing the system to burp. the upper radiator hose got hot but the lower radiator hose never changed temperature. the engine reached 178 degrees Fahrenheit. surprised, i drove on the highway for twenty minutes. at most, the coolant reached 182 degrees. the lower radiator hose still felt cold when I got home.

the radiator is supposed to cool the coolant of course but shouldn’t the lower radiator hose get at least a LITTLE warm? due to the lack of engine overheating, is my radiator just performing well? am I making a big deal out of nothing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358388
If you're not overheating then you have good coolant flow and your radiator is working very well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358392
But shouldn’t the lower radiator hose get at least a LITTLE warm? This means the thermostat won’t open — correct? If the radiator performs too well then the engine will simply use the recirculate the same coolant — yes?

I realize how retarded I sound; this simultaneously makes sense and no sense to me at the same time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358405
It means that when the thermostat is opening, the radiator is cooling it enough that it's not heating the rubber of the hose enough for you to notice.
If you didn't have water flow your engine temperature would be spiking and you'd be boiling coolant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358405
If the input hose to the radiator is hot and the output hose isn't even warm, it may be a clog in the radiator. Alternatively if retarded design allows the thermostat to be installed backwards, that may be a possibility.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358418
You’re right.

I realized my point of confusion: I thought the thermostat was located after the radiator but that makes no sense. The thermostat’s job is to measure coolant temperature relative to the engine NOT the radiator. It would make no sense to place the thermostat after the radiator flow-wise because that temperature measurement would be a measurement of radiator performance.

Hopefully that explains why I was confused.

Sorry to be a retard.

Saging my own thread as punishment.

I wouldn't recommend driving it for a long time, if the o2 sensor is bad, which is a pretty minor repair repair that sets off the check engine light, your car doesn't know what's going on in the exhaust anymore, and it may not get the air fuel mixture right, which means your car might start running a richer fuel mixture than normal, and it's not healthy to be dumping more fuel into the catalytic converter, which can cost your more in repairs than just the o2 sensor that was being ignored.

The paint layer may not technically deteriorate, but enjoy your white paint literally falling off because it doesn't block UV fully so the modern eco water based primer underneath gets sunburnt and fails.

>"The reason the paint fails most commonly in that area is that those areas take the most beating from the sun. The paint (primer, primer sealer, basecoat & clear coat) weren't thick enough to block the UV so it damaged the ecoat which being epoxy, doesn't like UV very much. It begins to chalk, thus forcing the paint to delaminate..

>You want to preserve as much of the ecoat (bottom layer) as much as possible, it's protecting the zinc phosphate layer, which on the body panels is protecting the galvanized substrate. You sand down to substrate you'll lose all of that. This is why there is damn near no better system than what the factory gave you in terms of corrosion protection. Those conversion wipes aren't worth squat... So, sand away the chalkiness of the ecoat to salvage it if possible and then go about the refinish process per usual with primer surface, sealer then basecoat and such."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26355322
>According to most studies the threshold for perceiving something as "instant" is around 100ms
For touch specifically, you are wrong. Unlike visual reactions which realistically are ~30FPS (0.5 Hz), your haptic (touch) system goes well into the KHz range meaning sub-ms delays will be perceptible. Now, this is still in a sense "slow" for electronics, but it requires non-trivial programming and hardware design to make mechanical objects move fast enough for a delay to be imperceptible *by your sense of touch*.

So in short, yes you can make a system responsive enough not to be noticeable, but it's non-trivial enough that a shitbox going for lowest cost might not do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one was going to be the 1997 car, but when the championship was canned, the project was shelved. Not unusual as often manufacturers will try something and then push it to one side, but what we have here is a mind-blowing Calibra that was entirely finished and ready to race aside from a sponsor’s livery.

But it wasn’t sold on, it wasn’t put out to dealers for demonstration; for some unfathomable reason it was parked in Zakspeed’s private museum and left.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Barring a few building changes this is where it’s stayed. But just look at it. How could you not want to see what it will do? Details are sparse, stories have probably shifted since Zakspeed built the Opel and all we’re told is that the manufacturer doesn’t want the car to be raced. And this is where that initial question comes back in: just imagine what would happen if it came out and could face the potential rivals. Run a series for ghost racers, just for kicks – how cool would that be? Would it have affected road car sales? Would the sums and technology do their job and win the race? It’s purely hypothetical and will always remain so, but hey I can dream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I ask one of the small Zakspeed team who are in the background as I’m left alone to shoot the Calibra if it will race one day. Once again he smiles and neither confirms nor denies it. This is all old, irrelevant technology for Opel – why would they want it wheeled out? To be honest I’m not even sure who completely owns the Calibra. It’s here but does that mean Zakspeed can do what they want with it? Obviously not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

The Taisan F40 got auctioned off a couple of years ago and went for roughly $1 million.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Taisan F40's History

The JGTC (Japan GT Championship) started in 1994 and it laid the foundation for what was to become Japan's top racing category, Super GT.

One of the cars that received particular attention in Japan’s rich racing history was a Ferrari.
The Team Taisan Star Card F40.

At the time, the Italian GT Championship saw European dream cars such as the Porsche 964 Carrera RS and the Jaguar XJ220 line-up against each other. But when Yasutsune Chiba, the head of Team Taisan, came across an article in a magazine about how the F40 was dominating in Europe, he couldn’t help but dream of the F40 racing around Japanese circuits.

Chiba immediately bought an F40 and showed it off at the Fuji Speedway for the opening round of the JGTC season. The red body-coloured supercar was, of course, the talk of the race fans and drew a lot of attention. At the time, however, F40 racing parts were hard to come by and the car had to be driven in a virtually stock configuration. Despite its reputation, the F40 struggled to keep up with the other teams, who had built their cars with a wealth of experience.

However, for Chiba, running the F40 in a Japanese race series meant a lot to him and he refused to give up, improving the car race by race. This gradually paid off and they took pole position at the 4th round in Sugo. The team then brought in Oscar Larrauri, a former Italian GT Championship driver, to drive the car and team to victory.

In 1994, in the final race of the season, held at the Mine Circuit, the F40 made a spectacular start and took the lead, but the 962C, also from Team Taisan, was following closely. A fierce battle ensued between the two cars, but in the end the F40 took the chequered flag in 1st place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They ended the 1994 season on a strong note but the following season however, the F40 was unable to perform to its full potential due to the full scale support for Japanese works cars and the introduction of new regulations. As a result, the F40’s victory at Mine in 1994 was its first and last one in JGTC.
But the spectacle of this beautiful car speeding around a Japanese circuit, made possible by the enthusiasm of Team Taisan, has left a lasting impression on many race fans and became a legend that will live on forever.

https://bhauction.com/en/private-sales/1988-taisan-star-card-f40-jgtc-ferrari-f40-street-jgtc-ver-2

posts.com: In my free time I like to think about random possible engine swaps in various cars considering how much shit brands tend to share with each other. For example the P2 Volvo S80 T6 uses the GM 4T65-E, and many FWD GM products do as well. The V6s in said GM products also happen to be identical to their RWD counterparts. My line of thinking is that if the Volvo 4T65-E is identical to a GM unit (bell housing and starter location), it would be possible to bolt up a Volvo B629T4 into a GM F-body. Inversely, you could L67 or LS4 swap an S80 if you so desired, but switching to an 4T65-HD would be preferred. Obviously the swaps would include the headache of a custom cooling system, engine mounts, engine management, etc. but mating the engine to the transmission shouldn't be to difficult. What crackpipe engine swap ideas are floating around in your heads?

>>26352701
This is all in your head, we literally do not give a shit how you pay for the car. We get paid the same either way. If you're claiming to finance and then bait and switch to cash you'll have to negotiate on OTD price anyway and the salesman will know and you'll probably get treated like shit because you came in, lied, and negotiated in bad faith. We do this shit for a living, 6 days a week... all year long.

There's no "tricks" to pwn the dealer and "win" because if we aren't making enough money on the sale we won't do the deal. It doesn't matter how you skin it, you're going to be paying 2-3k over invoice at minimum or you aren't leaving with the car. Whether that's in the form of warranties, protection, markup, whatever... it makes no difference.

How to actually buy a car: Call ahead, remember salesman's name that you spoke to. Ask for them when you arrive, be nice, drive the car and make your offer. Give them all the info they ask for and assure them you'll buy that same day if you can agree on price. Be patient, you'll typically get 2-3 counter offers from the salesman before a sales manager comes in and presents his counter. If that one isn't low enough for you just shake his hand, thank him for his time, remind them that they have your phone # and to call you if they can match your offer, then just leave. Don't stick around all day, 2 hours maximum, if they are willing to do the deal they will call you back in.

t. car salesman

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26358355
Negotiate on OTD (out the door) price. Meaning the total cost of every component of the sale, standard for cash deals, if you're financing this isjust down payment + total amount financed (+ trade value if applicable). If they give you the runaround and do the old school "4 square" method and start scribbling numbers by hand, politely ask them to print out an itemized breakdown of OTD price for you so you can see it all tabulated out.

A reasonable offer would be msrp + tax + doc fee + registration/plate fee.

That will basically be bottom dollar, they may be able to get there, they may not. Typically that nets the dealer ~1k gross profit because of the inflated fee charges. Some dealers may do that deal but almost everyone will REALLY push for at least one warranty or dealer add package because they need to sell a certain number of those for other reasons. (Ideally they want to make close to their average which is likely around ~$3500 right now).

Reminder: paint protection, nitrogen, wheel and tire coverage etc. is all just profit and is essentially the same as just pricing the car that much higher. Treat it as such. When the salesman pushes super hard for them just understand he's not trying to sell you on snake oil he just needs to justify a higher price so the dealer can hit it's margins and he can get his sale, if they get flustered and stuck on the ads/services/warranties/fees and keep saying shit like "it's already on the car you have to pay for it" that likely means you've sucked all the money out of the deal and they are trying to hold any little bit of profit they can so they can actually make the deal.

I've been thinking about restorations recently or moreso how I would restore one, because I would like an older muscle car but at the same time would prefer a car to perform to modern standards and was stuck on where I would stand when it comes to how I would go about it
this led to me realizing when it comes to dogma on restorations, especially older/classic cars, it essentially exists on a spectrum with 2 opposite ends and 2 major points between them
>restoring the car to perfect oem condition; the way it rolled out of the factory
>restoring the car with aftermarket performance parts available at the time period of the car
>restoring the internals, motor, suspension, etc. using modern parts but otherwise restoring the rest of the car to as it was out of the factory
>a total restomod leaving very little of the car in it's original state
where on this spectrum would you guys fall?
if I were trying to be a purist, what would you say is the amount of new/modern parts or what exactly could be replaced for an older car that would still maintain it's OEM purity as a classic car?

OEM+

Good:

>using better parts that are known problem areas for the car originally, such as the infamous IMS bearing or Optispark in old GM LT1's

Bad:
>replacing R12 with R134 for your AC, R134 sucks, sometimes the condenser isn't powerful enough to chill the cabin
>replacing drums with discs
>EFI carbs, or whatever the fuck those Sniper EFI kits are
>replacing old dashes with new digital dashes, or needlessly adding gauges
>aftermarket radios, I don't care if it's Kenwood, Pioneer, whoever, they ALL look like complete shit. you can add bluetooth to a base GM radio, get your solder skills up

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26358404
This is usually a bad idea, and I reject every car with aftermarket-anything when it comes to audio. Most cars I've worked on have their propriety wiring (GM, Bose) when it comes to the amps and speakers, so you'll need to create adapters just to get your stuff to work and only if you're lucky, when you could've just resoldered the amps or replaced the OEM speakers already in the car. Though most people selling cars will just completely take apart the wiring harness like retards and splice wires together with fucking wire nuts.

I'm sure there's some exceptions to this, like the abysmal audio in an FD RX-7, but even then the stock audio has a certain charm to it. Just don't swap out the radio, I want to kill everyone that does that to a classic.

If it was notchy with a lightweight flywheel and fresh thrust and pilot bearings toss some fresh hydraulics on there and make sure you are using GL4 trans fluid. I've done fidanza flywheel and oem clutch on a few miatas and it always turns the shifting experience to 11/10 but worn synchros are a thing and a lot of Miata faggots power through the shifts even when the thrust and pilot bearing are gritty. >>26352868
really easy if you have a brocker. I use Bpro (mainly because alberta has a 0% PST and his fees are cheaper than anyone in my shithole lel). I pay him a 1K fee and tell him what car i want and give him a budget.

You bid at auction until you find something interesting and if you win you pay him the amount due(Shipping,broker fee,customs,etc generally hover between 3-4.5k on top of the car price).

Then the fun part begin and you wait for your car while it sit in a boat to travel the pacific. Generally it takes 2 months(pre covid waiting time was 1 month but now OE have the priority for the boats).

Generally it'll drop in Vancouver. Your broker will take care for the customs and all that shit. He can also arrange delivery of your car to your place via train. The closer you live from Vancouver the cheaper the train will be.(For reference I live in the Montreal region and my bills are around 1.5k T_T)

>>26355390
>going up to 85 psi
I must be a bitch since I prefer to just go to 40 or 50 and manipulate the tire to get it on when it's not inflated.

There is a line that goes around the tire next to the bead. The line should have a "reveal" that shows the bead is seated evenly accross the tire. I suspect your tire is not seated in a specific spot.
What I do is deflate, lube the shit out of it in that spot, and make sure that spot inflates first/early and seats.
Generally I have good luck with that. Just keep trying and you will figure it out.

Anyways There are many options for grips. I find you have the hard plastic OEM style grips, medium, soft, and thicker grips too choose from.

sounds like you haven't actually seated the bead at all. i'd lever it back into the centre of the rim and lube up the bead again the whole way around. what are you using for lube? i use euro tire paste but i've heard of guys using wd40 (!) for really stubborn beads. also are you inflating with the valve cores out? speed of inflation probably matters more than max pressure although i used to use a bicycle pump to do mine so lube is the most important thing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26355731
What I do with a stubborn section is undo the semi seated part of the tire, let it be relaxed. Then I start from the part that didn't seat, and get that tight and effectively move the recessed part to the opposite side.
This tend to work for me. If it's a tubeless tire you will of course hear the pops. If it's tubed I have seen it not really pop, just a slow creep of the bead going out until it's good.
Just takes time man.

>>26346055
This is why I went C5:
-lightest Corvette with remotely modern design/manufacturing (some early ones were slightly lighter but they're built like an ox cart in comparison)
-modern enough to be reliable, old enough to be analog and TCS/Stability can be disabled with one press of a button
-proper 6 speed manual with the legendary T56
-enough power to spin all the way to 50 mph and possibly up to 75 depending on available grip
-unbelievably low CG, at speeds a crossover would feel like it was going to flip I can go +20mph though the same corner.
-one of the last Corvettes a normal human can work on without begging the dealer for help
-Pop up up and down headlights
-one of the most forum documented cars ever made, literally any peep of an issue and there's an autistic write up about how to fix it
-MPG isn't even that bad, most economy cars barely did better from the same era.
-front engine means it's more stable and predictable, MRs can be faster flat out but are also more likely to snap and kill you. Fine on a track with lots of runoff, less fine on the street. Front engine is also much easier to work on, which might be the biggest reason keeping me from ever getting a C8+.

>boredom in six months

>lots of electronic nannies
So turn them off. Literally press one button for five seconds and they're gone.
>and a shitload of performance you'll never use
This is the only legitimate criticism. Stomping the throttle in this car means hitting illegal speeds in seconds, or a fuckton of wheel spin if you've disabled traction control and ESC as noted above. Thankfully everything else is so well sorted dynamically that you can enjoy driving the car regardless of speed.

>>26347110
I went C5 first and foremost because I wanted to own a car with pop up headlights before they all become ancient unreliable shitheaps. While all JDM cars with pop ups have shot to the moon in price even in shitty condition, I noticed C5s were astonishingly cheap, far cheaper than I ever would've imagined. The more I looked into them, the more I realized they were everything I wanted in a car.

The fact I got a bargain was just icing on the cake. I had an FR-S I bought new in cash in 2013 before this car and came out to around $30k and I make more now than I did then, so I could've spent far more if I wanted to, but I didn't need to and that's great. I can't bring myself to spend more than $30k on a car, there's too many diversity-Americans roaming around nowadays that will target expensive cars and I don't want to have to deal with coming back to busted windows, keyed doors, etc. every 5 days regardless of cost. I barely even drive the C5 to most locations because even though it's not that expensive, people *perceive it to be* and I don't want that kind of attention.

>Is it true what they say about the P71's ECU "cop tuning" being more responsive?
The "cop chip" is an ongoing joke. The P71 and other panthers have the same engine/transmission/tune. The biggest difference is the P71 had different rear end options, higher ride height, extra oil/trans cooler, thicker sway bars, relocated gas tank, and some other small stuff.

>I wanna buy one, seen some good examples locally, but I don't want to overpay. Most I see are running from 6-9k but I really only wanna pay 5k or under

lmao do you live in San Francisco or New York? I'm in the midwest and panthers are still cheap as fuck. My grand marquis has 150k miles, no dents, scratches, or accidents, no check engine light, everything working fine. No history of accidents on carfax etc. I couldn't sell it so I stopped trying. I had it listed for $3k on facebook marketplace a while ago. I was hoping to sell it and then use that money to buy myself an LS400, but the LS400 prices took off in the meantime. Unfortunately I only ever got 3 or 4 people who even messaged me about the car, and like half of them were mexicans who literally live over a thousand miles away in mexico.

I routinely see good looking panthers on fb marketplace for under 5k and most of them are well under 150k miles, sometimes well under 100k miles.


The only thing I would advise though, is to get the lowest mileage for the price that you can. These cars are fairly reliable and bulletproof, but once they get closer to 200k miles is where a lot of things can go wrong if you haven't done preventative maintenance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26357733
The real deal is production speed not repair or troubleshooting speed. Any process time they can reduce means more profit. Repair mechanics operate under different constraints.

Computers and software are cheaper than mechanical controls to produce by a vast margin and performance requirements cannot be met with crude systems. Modern engine management, braking and traction control could not be effectively done by simple hydro-mechanical systems (like Bosch CIS fuel injection or hydro-mechanical automatic gear boxes.

I do object to vendor locked software since that's pure rent-seeking having nothing to do with quality maintenance. It's just gatekeeping. For example early GM PCMs can be flashed and their bins easily modified using LSDroid or PCM Hammer to download, using Universal Patcher to change paramaters and DTC codes, then the modified bin flashed to the PCM but that's no thanks to the factory, only to the government for mandating standards then curious coders writing the software and giving it away. (The LSDroid business model of giving away software but selling inexpensive Bluetooth flashing adapters is ethica and makes hardware sellers a tidy profit for their work. They benefit from the tuning community

The factory subscription model isn't cheap but makes sense. Updating tech data can be done for central servers without pushing paper pubs. (The Air Force switched because printing then maintaining and manually updating a Technical Order library is time consuming and leaves too much room for error.)

>>26357619
The right way is only memorize the simplest processes and always refer to tech data. That's why if the most experienced engine mech, avionics puke or load toad doesn't have their job guide or checklist open be it paper or electronic QA rightly have their arse. Fundamental to quality wrenching is understanding facts change and don't care about one's feelings any more than the machine being repaired.

Wrote with the head of the Opel museum in Rüsselsheim on Insta, did a Q&A.

Wrote that Opel built about 65 Opel Omega Bs with the LS1 from the Corvette, and not 30 like most parrot online.
Both sedan and wagon version where built, and even sold (pre ordered).
He himself own a sedan and a wagon version, plus a Omega A with a LS.

The story of them overheating is not true at all, and that this was only invented to kill the car without people asking questions.
Here is the kicker, according to him BMW bribed Opel/GM executives to kill the car in the last minute (right around the time of the beginning of the production).
The reason he said was that the LS1 powered Omega would've been a huge problem for the 3 series and the 5 series.
The LS1 powered Opel would've been much cheaper than the BMWs fully spect out, and the risk of it cutting into BMWs sales around Europe would've been a to big of a risk to allow it to be built.

All convertible fox body mustangs started off as a notchback.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26355609
Unironically, go karts. My first racing vehicle was a 200cc briggs & stratton powered single gear go kart. I towed that sucker behind a miata on the cheapest trailer from Lowes with every tool I owned stuffed in the trunk and under the roll bar. Took it to the kart track every other weekend, and took it to the big tracks too. My glorified lawn mower turned lap times as good as a spec miata or spec racer ford. Really cheap to run, tires last multiple weekends and it runs on clear gas from regular gas stations. After that I raced stock honda cr125 shifter karts which cost more to run but can annihilate an exotic street car on a race track. While I raced I slowly collected more tools, better tow vehicle, bigger trailer, etc. Rented rides in a few different types of cars. Now I drive a formula continental but the only startup cost was the car itself. It's an extremely good value class in terms of speed per dollar spent and there are decent sized fields to race in, albeit nothing compared SM or SRF. You get to have a modern spaceframe racecar with pushrod suspension and downforce but costs are kept pretty minimal as no carbon fiber is allowed to touch air so the wings are aluminum and diffuser fiberglass which forces the designs to be simpler. I highly recommend it. But for the truly lowest budget racer? Go karts all the way. The shifter could do 0-60 in about 3.5 seconds and could peak at 3 Gs laterally in banked corners.

High roof and low floor makes it roomy. I can take an mtb with me to work then go to the trail and stand up from the seat and walk to the back and sit down and get changed out of my work clothes. I can sleep back there because there is over 6 feet of linear space from the front passengers seat all the way forward to the back. I can also open the tailgate and extend the flat floor to over 7 feet for two to sleep side by side. Tailgate is also the perfect height to move a chair up to and be used as a work bench. It does this while still being quite short and easy to city park. If I stop by a thrift store on the way one I can grab that dresser instead of having to go home and come back with my truck. posts.name: Panda5
posts.com:
>>26353877
My last car came with a 1.5" hole in the midpipe. It was a stock miata so it sounded awful.
Here's the sure-fire way to fix it if it's in the pipe and not right on a connector:
-Get exhaust repair putty and exhaust tape (both are called various things)
-Make sure the engine/exhaust is cold and clean the area
-Apply exhaust putty and dry it according to instructions. Then apply another layer and dry that.
-Get 2 soda cans. Cut the ends off and make a cut lengthwise to the can - it should be a C-shape.
-Put the soda shell around the pipe.
-Apply the exhaust tape per instructions (some make you dip it in a compound, some you have to get wet, and some you just apply. Follow the instructions on curing/drying the tape - you may have to drive the car for a while to do it.
-Apply the second can shell and another (thicker) round of exhaust tape (make sure to let the exhaust cool if you drove it to finish the 1st tape).
It just works, my car was suddenly quiet. $15 at VatoZone for the tape and putty.

It's not permanent. The mangled red blood cells die after a while, continually replaced by fresh unmangled ones. You might as well worry about grilling with charcoal outside because chance are you're going huff more CO2 than when you're lying in your hugbox with with a pair of alex jones' magic air cleaners standing guard at each side of every doorway and window.

It really depends where the leak is and if it's constantly drafting in to the cabin or not. Depending on his setup, being after even one catalytic converter might cut the bulk of it out. If it's behind all of them then the danger is approximately nonexistent and he might as well also be worried about huffing unburnt hydrocarbons (chronic exposure to which can carry a certain danger of permanent brain damage, but which typically mostly resolves itself once the offending source of huffing gasses is removed).

It's like prostate cancer. Everybody develops prostate cancer. But most people either die from something else first or it does not present symptoms or dangers worth doing anything rash about.

Is Midnight Club 3 the best arcade racer ever?
Pros:
>Unparalleled sense of speed
>difficult to master handling system that is extremely rewarding when you master it, especially with tail happy cars like the Viper GTS R
>diverse cities, that feel really lived in
>way more in touch with the racing scene in the era than it's competitors
>no bullshit story
>good difficulty curve
>great and fitting soundtrack
>graphics don't look horrible, but not as good as MW

Cons:
>lackluster vehicle list, most of the tuners are just muscle cars (in what world is a C5 Corvette or a Viper a fucking tuner? )
>Only a handful of JDM cars, the game is partially set in Tokyo for God's sake
>No one except the mechanics has any personality, including the drivers, a huge downgrade from MC2
>car models are total dogshit in compared to Most Wanted (see the Viper for a good comparison)

Did i miss anything? I genuinely believe that if it were released on PC it would be still popular today

>>26337453
I think the car list is one of the best that represents the era IMO. You've got some land yachts, oddball SUVs you don't often see in games from a Yukon Denali to an Infiniti FX (+the popular ones, too), oddball luxury cars such as the VW Phaeton and Lexus SC430, and even some concept cars such as the Dodge Super 8 Hemi, Cadillac Cien and Chrysler ME-412. There could've been a few more tuners, but it was 'DUB Edition' and going more for that blingy theme. V8 Dodge Chargers and Lotus Esprits are definitely not tuners by any means however.
The Tokyo setting was also added as an afterthought in Remix and it itself was a rehash of the Tokyo map in MC2, though I found it rather disappointing that you don't even win any Japanese cars there outside of the Nissan concept car (and the Infiniti G35 technically, though it's in USDM form)
The customization is still top tier, however. I love how the majority of cars offer bodykits all from real brands of the era, and how you can even mess with individual tire sizes to go bigger/smaller to your tastes. A full livery editor would've made it nearly perfect.

>>26338747
I got you brah. Look up ACTK-fr - I recommend them as the go-to for cars in general since they don't just collect and reupload them, but add LODs and fix some issues here and there, making them immediately better than what a lot of the original authors post since they can't bother to optimize their shit, specifically all the asshats that just try to sell their garbage on Patreon, not that there aren't good (free) car mods to be had on there and other similar sites. There are plenty of street cars and tracks on RaceDepartment, if you can't find what you're looking for on either of those sites, look up Totsugeki - mostly Japanese cars and better presentation of what to expect. Assettoland would probably be the next place to check, though IMO it's kind of a disorganized clusterfuck after it got shutdown like three times for sharing payware cars. As for people on Patreon: Dan Bucsa, MacedoSTI, VR driving, Jerry Wei/伯瑜 魏, DanielDi, Just Kapi, etc. You can find a bunch of cars and shit searching on jewtube too. I'd say don't bother with the Cut Up No Hesi servers unless you really want a specific car and have space, most of the cars in their packs are half-baked garbage, though their traffic pack I would say is the gold standard. Freeroam maps and driving with traffic? Search YouTube. There's a bunch now, though the best ones that I've tried are LA Canyons, Pacific Coast Highway, Union Island, High Force, and Shutoko Revival Project. You'll have to get into discord servers to get download links to a lot of content too. Touge Union and Kami Trick have some nice content floating around. Currently 2REAL is the best traffic simulation but it's singleplayer only. If you want to do multiplayer with friends with AI traffic, look up Assetto Server. Their documentation makes it simple, if you can't figure it out, you're a brainlet.

$640? You're looking in the wrong places. The G920 and G29 have regularly gone on sale for $200 ($50-$60 for the shifter) for years. Keep an eye on eBay and Goodwill/other online auctions, you can score those used or the older G27/G25 for under $200, just be sure to verify that it works first unless you're handy at repairing electronics. Considering some of the wheels on the market are 20 years old, I'd say they're built pretty well. If you are willing to get the G25/G27, try to go for the ones that have the shifter that can convert between H-pattern and sequential. And if it's not a motion capable cockpit with six degrees of freedom, it's a meme as far as I'm concerned, just plop the wheel onto your desk and call it a day. Desk too small? Buy a new desk or find one off the craigslist free section, or build your own faggoty static cockpit for under $100.

>>26341643
as i said the heavy v8 actually interferes with what is otherwise an extremely precise grand tourer
all the effort that went into making sure the v8 can turn at all simply means the v6 turns better, and the fact that it loses weight over the front axle specifically changes the dynamics for the better. the less powerful engine allows you to lay on it at the apex and steer through with the throttle without any tc intervention, the lighter chassis turns quicker and stops faster, and personally my hellcat diff swap is the cherry on top of a corner carving cake. i have ran with tuned widebody bmws and audis on the dragon, that fat bitch can fuckin scoot believe me.

on top of all that it's a class of car nobody else actually makes (cheap executive coupe) with a style unmatched by anything sold this couple of decades. there is nothing else like a chally wally. yes you could have a v6 camry or accord, probably cheaper, just as fast, but not rwd.
you could have a bmw 3-series, lighter, smaller, more powerful, better on gas, but it doesn't have the road presence of an actively exploding nuclear bomb, or you could have a camaro v6 with a stick and not be able to see behind or fit anything in your trunk, or you could have a mustang and be the reason nobody likes v6s, or you could have a miata and be endlessly hit on by mustang owners, etc
can you get a cool looking car that's simple, reliable, easy to maintain, not too new, not too old, handles good, seats more than two and hauls lots of stuff, that has literally no downsides or compromises compared to any other automobile, sold like a customizable burrito with an increasingly spicier selection of sauce to eat it with? a car that has worldwide acclaim and desire approaching ferrari levels yet it's just literally a rwd dodge stratus with a bodykit you can buy for 10k off cl?
yes you can.
it's the god machine, the chally wally.

>>26350247
Kaz is the most powerful individual in the racing game/sim racing community. Is it because he raced the midnight club, raced in the VLN and has class wins in the Nurb24? Is it because his studio is a PS first party? Possibly
But it's most certainly because he has a network with automotive enthusiasts, race car drivers and teams, governing bodies but most importantly, manufacturers.
At the end of the day, a racing game is only as good as its cars. And GT was one of the first games to introduce extensive licensing amongst multiple large automotive marques.
Kaz not only convinced a bunch of zaibatsu bean counters to let him out their cars into a video game but then maintained a relationship with Nissan and further convinced them "hey we're going to put a bunch of nerds that are the best in the world at a video game and as long as they don't kwab at the irl g forces they will win races".
And surprisingly it worked, but most importantly because they produced decent results and Nissan and GT thought the money invested into the GT Academy scheme was valuable marketing. Kaz has definitely been dialing down his efforts though, I think he's getting too old to race and do GT and his racing spirit has diminished. It will be a shame when he does inevitably retires but I think he should decide soon and elect a worth successors to fill his shoes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26323776

Audi and Subaru both committed the entire brand to the set up. Subaru uses compact boxer engines to reduce the weight and distribution of that weight. Audi intially wanted a 4 cylinder as well to keep weight down and a 6 cylinder was too much weigh too far forward so they ran 5 cylinders for a very long time. Then they developed very small compact engines to reduce the effect. The current V8 in the RS6 is shorter than the old inline 5 and cast out of aluminum.

They also have innovated the transaxle to allow the engine to sit more rearward than before so the weight distribution is more around 54/44 than the older 61/39.

Audi and Subaru do not get a pass. They get mocked all the time for the Achilles heel. But they’re significantly better than the acura situation which has no means to addrsss the problem, and really no need too since nobody expects an Acura or Honda ti be fun to drive

>fuckin dope. what was it like?
Had it from 2013 to 2022. Honestly it was a great car so long as you kept on top of it. Mine was in kind of rough shape and needed a motor rebuild when I bought it which is did in the first year. After that it was my daily driver until about 2018.

When I was driving it every day it was great. I had weird issues like when I needed to have the computer replaced because the sauder started coming apart.

The Problems didn't really start until I changed jobs and suddenly had a commute that was 30 miles instead of 5 and involved driving on the busiest parts of the freeway and downtown. I bought myself a Saab for $1500 and the 944 turned into my "weekend car"

Then I moved and it had to go into storage and just started to rot from lack of use. I finally let it go to a guy who was working on my mom's house last summer because it was his favorite model of Porsche. I figured it was better going to a good home than rotting away in a storage unit because my apartment wouldn't let me park 2 cars and the office complained about it being "loud"

If you have any intention of getting a 944 do the research that I didn't when I bought mine and wait until you find one of the at least decently kept ones. Otherwise be prepared to sink a grand a year into all the random shit that will break that you will never expect.

>>26332122
that's me, what do you need to know?
there are guides all over the place, but the main thing is access. you HAVE to permanently damage something, but what you actually damage is your choice:
>go through the wiper blade motor / battery area and have to destroy the baffle housing itself
>go through the dash and destroy the vent ducting (route i took, see the huge gashes in the vent and the taped column of plastic held down by painters tape)
in my picture >>26327489 you can see the metal baffle. well, that's one of two baffles. the one you can see if the diverter for vent directionality. the other is just to the left of it and diverts air through the heater core.
you have to do both. i used Gorilla's flex seal competitor tape since it's so wide and kinda soft. i poked little holes all over it to replicate whatever Porsche was thinking by using permeable foam instead of a solid aluminum baffle. maybe the porous nature of the foam keeps the servos from slamming when the baffles fire under fan pressure or something.

>pic for bumping

Couldn't turn down a stupid inexpensive 987s last year from a friend. It does have oiling issues after autoxing with sticky tires and aggressive driving. It ticks for 30 seconds or so after a run. So I'm just driving it for fun to compliment the race car for the next year or two as I setup my shop with a lift. Then I'll sell the low mile M97 and swap in another engine, likely audi 4.2 v8.

The chassis and steering are magical for what it is, the brakes are fantastic even if the pedal is a little spongy. The Gearbox is passable and shifter is meh. The engine feels pretty decent driving it around making some nice noises and the response change around 5k rpm feels like german vtec. If it didn't have oiling issues or eventual bore scoring I'd definitely keep the engine and do some bolt ons.
